caption: It's still the same Coruscant, but there have been a few changes since...er.. before you saw it last.
The Imperials in this level do their best, but in the end it's not quite enough.
The bridge is just one example of the detail and accuracy the author put into this level.
"The Force is with you Katarn... but you are not a Jedi yet."
Superb lighting and texturing really allow this level to shine.
There's no mistaking this scene. The Imperials are renovating Yavin, and you have to stop them.
The architecture in this level is beautifully done, with textures well done and placed wisely to give the right look.
Again, wonderful texture placement sets the mood, along with good lighting to accent. Notice also how the textures line up very nicely and accurately.
The Imperials have decided to crash the party.
Little touches in the architecture and design(note the see-through grating) pay off big in this level.
A Mos Eisley stormtrooper complete with larger rifle and a new "dark" trooper are nice touches to this level.
New and old textures find their way into this level with some good results...
...and some not so good results.
Flat, boring, easy. Yup, it's Wolfenstein.
The mission grabs your attention with a nice first view. The thermal detonator immediately lobbed in your direction also helps.
Little details like the officer inspecting non-functional Dark Trooper prototypes elevate the setting.
Find the controls that extend the bridge! Blasting them recommended.
Subtle lighting differences let the textures pop and focus the player's attention on the objective.
Coober: what you see is what you get. I can't even come up with something funny to say.
Your job in the second level is to steal an Imperial IFF device, hidden somewhere in this docking facility.
In the first level, Kyle needs to make his way onto a Corvette (left side) carrying a deadly cargo.
Several different styles, including many large open areas, are combined with thought and skill to form the depot.
The Crow waits to be liberated from its docking bay in the first level of this extensive set.
Nice looking WAXs help to bring the new characters of DF96 to life.
Is this familiar to you? New ideas are combined with old to create a truly unique experience.
The author has set up many great looking areas in this level, and most are very difficult to reach. They also fail to serve a purpose.
The monastary has been done very well, and almost has a gothic feel to it.
You can note how the textures and architecture are lined up very precisely and accurately.
Nicely done new rock and sky textures really enhance the level's atmosphere.
You round the corner to see a large metal structure. You raise your head and look up, and up...
The damage caused by the Imperial assault is still present.
Every part of the Rebel base is now filled with Imperial troops, so best be cautious.
The Imperials are flooding the area with probe droids in an attempt to locate the Corellian commander before you do.
Spend enough time in the twisting caverns of Hoth and you may discover some new life forms (or start hallucinating, I'm not sure).
This hangar is an example of the wide open places the author has managed to create without any HOMing.
The author is very fond of large windows, many of which overlook huge open areas of the city.
The old facility has been given a new look, and new areas have been added to revive this old level.
You're in a tight spot at your initial drop point.
It's a serviceable Imperial facility, but nothing new.
The author claims the mission is difficult, but a single Phase 1 Dark Trooper isn't particularly challenging.
Individual rooms are packed with troops, but again, that's not really hard.
These new graphics are a lot like the level; an interesting attempt, but they fall short.
Grandiose architecture, a suspenseful story, and an excellent feel for what works well in a level combine to make this a great play.
Ah, Coruscant! This level does a nice job of depicting the huge bustling city with close-packed buildings, and typical sterile Imperial architecture.
A statement about the level of commercialization in society today? This level is nothing more than a large advertisement.
Well... to each their own, I guess.
There are lots of problems with this level; unfortunately many, like this one, are very obvious.
There are several large open areas with lots of detail and no HOMing.
One of the deep access elevators is located near the sewer system; but where is it?
The choice of textures and attention to details (note the shading) is what really makes the Academy come to life.
The Imperials throw everything at you in a last ditch effort to stop your plans to destroy the Academy.
A lack of good texture choices and bad architecture leaves this level floundering.
The author has doen a great job with this hotel, expertly combining familiar ideas with new ones.
An example of a typical room. There's some detail to keep each room alive, but they're all pretty blocky.
There are some intersting ideas in this level but nothing really spectacular.
The author has created familiar sights using basic geometry.
Secrets abound in this mini mission.
Your home has been transformed through the power of the Jedi engine, and it's not very friendly.
Even though the author has recycled his previous Tatooine level, he still adds several new surprises to give the experience some freshness.
Right from the start things are a little different from what you might remember.
The revised mission will give you plenty of opportunity to use the arsenal it provides.
Some of the logics applied to WAXes make for disturbing and hilarious new combinations.
You get to run around inside a jawa sandcrawler. And that's about it.
For the second time you fight for the Empire, still trying to track down the plans for the SSSD Sovereign; this time on Tatooine.
Most of the areas in this level are pretty bland and disimilar. Others, like this one, are just plain ugly.
Uhm, Jan, I don't think we're in Kansas anymore.
Enemies enhanced with multiple logics now have the ability to blow you sky high.
In this level you get to fight for the Dark Side for a change.
This is the more interesting half of the 'level'.
Poor texture decisions and the addition of dozens of new files weigh this level down.
Inventive new ways to use the Dark Forces engine abound in this mission.
The combination of sound design and elaborate INF programming brings the environment to life.
Mission Imp... erial?
New VUEs make the cloning facility feel like an active base, not a ghost town.
Each area feels lovingly and uniquely crafted.
We've seen many of these kinds of places before, but never with this level of detail and custom work.
The story unfolds as you progress through the mission, giving you an enhanced sense of urgency to complete your objectives.
What exactly is going on within the Mt. Kurek facility?
This area might look nice but it serves no purpose other than to slow down the computer.
Here's a shot that's pretty standard. Right angles, poor texture placing... pretty boring.
A custom briefing might seem like table stakes for a great mission now, but doing it right with custom artwork is all part of the experience.
The nighttime setting of the castle on Gamorra establishes a threatening ambience right away.
Special touches like an underwater area showcase the inventiveness of this author.
The castle is a great mix of old and new textures, Imperial and medieval architecture.
Come to papa...
The castle and other settings may be great, but what steals the show is the new weapon you find: The Black Whirlwind.
As with many levels based in the movies, this one recreates what we all know well, adding in subtle twists to bend it to the author's wishes.
New FMEs and WAXes help the mission really come alive.
The architecture gives you the feeling of Mos Eisley, and makes you understand the title of "The Maze"
Secrets and in-jokes are abundant in the various Mos Eisley buildings.
While this mission is more than just movie references, it's definitely fun to encounter recognizable spaces.
Droids aren't welcome here, and neither are you.
The author seems quite fond of large open spaces and huge chasms, and uses them to accent the mood of the level.
This new TIE Fighter 3DO is great, but the rest of the level doesn't tend to fare as well.
You've been captured on your way back with the plans; now you have to get them back and escape.
An entire legion of my best troops awaits them...
Being able to look across the level to see the landing pad where you had been moments earlier makes the space feel real.
New 3DOs and VUEs are sprinkled throughout, though they don't feel tightly integrated with the story.
Yep, it's a bathroom. But thankfully it's used for more than just a snicker.
The trigger-happy nature of the game feels a little more justified when you're confronted with Imperial atrocities.
The author should be commended for using Boba Fett for more than just another fight, though I wish the standing frame had been placed here.
Some spaces are nicely decorated, and enemies and items are well-placed, but taken as a whole the geometry never really becomes something special.
You'll see a number of long hallways and textures that don't quite line up. And you just know there's something waiting for you on the other side of that overhang.
You can never tell if the droids are decoration or agressive, nor what kind of attack logic they've been imbued with.
One of the more interesting parts of the level is here in this large water tank.
Actually I didn't know one could venture out into space through a hangar door. Certainly not without health hazards.
Those Imperials work fast! They've converted Tak Base to their own uses.
The author has created a wonderful Tatooine atmosphere, complete with new WAXs, 3DOs, and VUEs.
One of the more interesting areas.
Get used to seeing lots of scenes like this if you try Rancor Base.
The mission kicks off with a high-stakes jumping puzzle as you escape your death sentence. It's downhill from there.
There are some nice ideas for set pieces, but they don't quite come together.
Lots of long, identical hallways, littered with PGUs and mines. Nobody would ever really build an outpost like this.
A few new items are scattered about as window dressing, never really amounting to much.
"Are we there yet?" The fleet is on its way to blast this place, so it's just as well if you don't feel compelled to stop and admire the craftsmanship.
It's Cloud City, alright.
You'll find numerous callbacks to settings in The Empire Strikes Back, though some are better executed than others.
It's Cloud City, alright.
New WAXes help this new setting feel distinct from any of the original Dark Forces levels.
The layout and texture work are top notch.
Your job is to hitch a ride on this crane.
Texturing is functional, but feels a little too clean for a run-down facility.
The architecture is also passable, but doesn't resemble a prison.
Some rooms better match the description, but the biggest issue is a disconnect between the narrative and design of the mission.
This level is a combo of good ideas, good ideas gone bad, and just plain BAD ideas.
Stormtroopers armed with cloaking devices are your new nemesis in this level.
What's your poison? In this hallway you select your opponents.
This scene is cool, but totally unnecessary, and it tends to blow what was looking really promising.
You've got to watch out; the Imperial attack continues to pound the base as you try to escape.
The author has done a beautiful job of recreating the Hoth base, right done to the ice caves it consisted of.
Instances where the author overlooked important details destroy any chance these levels ever had.
Endor? Looks more like a swamp on Dagobah. Perhaps the author needs to review his Star Wars again...
The author has managed to go beyond the normal confines of a "prison" level, adding in several new ideas.
Good choice in textures gives exterior locations interest and some believability.
The hangars have the same standard features we expect, but the author still makes sure you don't go by without a second look.
The author has taken cues from Dark Forces and other Star Wars experiences to expand the Arc Hammer and Executor, as well as modify the atmosphere to suit the level.
The mountain range of Relion has been beautifully rendered and meshed with the Imperial center.
Have we seen this before? This level shares more than a name with a certain movie.
Landspeeders help populate the city in this mission; too bad you can't take one for a spin.
Kyle must steal the plans for the Emperor's new starfighter.
New ideas and creations abound in this level.
You are to infiltrate a base and secure the plans for the Empire's newest weapon, the TIE Defender.
The entrance to the freighter is nicely done.
Imperial architects definitely aren't subtle. You'll know when you've found the underground facility.
It seems that they might be researching more than just Dark Troopers. Or maybe the poor kell dragon is target practice...
Don't worry, they don't bite. In this level you infiltrate the facility believed to have created the first DT prototype.
You'll find this style of room repeated quite often.
